comments.body:
if I understand the ticket correctly, the behavior is fine and the ticket is just about what happens in the logs, yeah?

If so, this is expected, AFAICT. maybe the log message is wrong, and we probably don’t need to log the exception.

before activating the app, we check if the app is already activated (https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/8bdf02be85f19ad222637306f7b292cf5aebdd2c/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/tsapi/service/AppService.java#L60), and app backend returns 404 if it isn’t activated (https://github.com/Tradeshift/App-Backend/blob/master/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/app/region/rest/AppActivationResource.java#L225). then we print the message and exception (https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/8bdf02be85f19ad222637306f7b292cf5aebdd2c/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/tsapi/service/AppService.java#L82).

Thanks for the links!

After looking over the code, the process is working as intended, but the wording of the exception message makes it seem as if app activation is not working altogether. Perhaps the exception message Exception occurred while connecting to app service while activating app for

should be updated to something like this:

The app is not activated on the company accoount

issuetype.description: A problem or error.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [EPManager] EPSellerDashboard App activation happens twice after activating enrollment

comments.body:
if I understand the ticket correctly, the behavior is fine and the ticket is just about what happens in the logs, yeah?

If so, this is expected, AFAICT. maybe the log message is wrong, and we probably don’t need to log the exception.

before activating the app, we check if the app is already activated ([https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/8bdf02be85f19ad222637306f7b292cf5aebdd2c/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/tsapi/service/AppService.java#L60|https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/8bdf02be85f19ad222637306f7b292cf5aebdd2c/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/tsapi/service/AppService.java#L60]), and app backend returns 404 if it isn’t activated ([https://github.com/Tradeshift/App-Backend/blob/master/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/app/region/rest/AppActivationResource.java#L225|https://github.com/Tradeshift/App-Backend/blob/master/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/app/region/rest/AppActivationResource.java#L225]). then we print the message and exception ([https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/8bdf02be85f19ad222637306f7b292cf5aebdd2c/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/tsapi/service/AppService.java#L82|https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/8bdf02be85f19ad222637306f7b292cf5aebdd2c/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/tsapi/service/AppService.java#L82]).

renderedFields.description: As a developer, I want to reduce the amount of time I spend creating programs and subscriptions in the user interface. When a platform event comes to early payments from Salesforce, the software does a lookup based on the Program Identifier in the Opportunity. If the software finds a program, it continues making the onboarding. If the software doesn't find a program, it throws an exception and crashes. I think the idea that we have to manually create programs for buyers is frustrating and doesn't scale well. Instead, if an Opportunity comes in from Salesforce and is completely filled out, the software can assume that it is correct and create a program for it.

renderedFields.description:
In the user interface for submitting bank details, the `data-tst="confirmation-checkbox"` element sits behind the data-spirit element. This is OK for live users, but for automated test software it isn't able to click the checkbox because it's hidden behind the data-spirit. Previously we were able to click it by targeting the `<div>` column holding the checkbox, but that's created a flaky testing environment where every time the text in that column shifts, there's a risk the test breaks, as it is right now. Can we please fix this so the checkbox sits on top of the data-spirit?

For this ticket to be complete, the user interface should be fixed, and the acceptance test should also be fixed to target the checkbox instead of its parent <div>.

fields.description:
In the user interface for submitting bank details, the `data-tst="confirmation-checkbox"` element sits behind the data-spirit element. This is OK for live users, but for automated test software it isn't able to click the checkbox because it's hidden _behind_ the data-spirit. Previously we were able to click it by targeting the `<div>` column holding the checkbox, but that's created a flaky testing environment where every time the text in that column shifts, there's a risk the test breaks, as it is right now. Can we please fix this so the checkbox sits on top of the data-spirit?



For this ticket to be complete, the user interface should be fixed, and the acceptance test should also be fixed to target the checkbox instead of its parent <div>.

!Screen Shot 2020-11-11 at 5.14.31 PM.png|width=200,height=183!

I want to be able to download all of a seller's enrollment data as a zip file
So I can share this with Blackstar and make it available in case of an audit

  • NOA Template filled with vIBANS (template being finalized)
  • Seller's bank details
  • Terms acceptance log
  • Platform terms (PDF of the version of platform terms accepted by the user)
  • Early Payment Terms (document being finalized)
  • RSA (document being finalized)

renderedFields.description:
ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "onboarding_company_unique"
Detail: Key (onboarding_id, company_account_id)=(ce5177d4-cfe9-48ff-80a3-08dc3a0a9431, 6f1eab4c-a17c-4b3c-9add-8b8a13dc4dc5) already exists.

https://sentry.io/organizations/tradeshiftcom/issues/2021308036/?project=1353182&referrer=slack

Fuller stack trace: https://sentry.io/organizations/tradeshiftcom/issues/2021308070/?project=1353182&referrer=slack

There is a violated database constraint. Here is the line of the migration that added the constraint: https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/5c9644a8f75300ebbd220908c2dbc8f9788c27ec/early-payments-service/src/main/resources/db/migration/V3.1__OnboardingBuyerSetup.sql#L28

When early payments saves Onboarding objects to the database, there are peripheral database objects, such as the Onboarding Supplier. My suspicion is that this line of code:
```Java
onboarding.setOnboardingBuyerSetups(Set.copyOf(buyerSetups));
```
https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/master/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/onboarding/handler/AbstractRfOnboardingHandler.java#L73

Should also set the ID of any existing buyer setups. I think, right now, it's trying to take existing buyer setup objects, create new objects from them, and then save them to the database, which is what causes the exception. I'm not sure how to stop Hibernate from trying to make a new database object and instead reuse an existing one.

renderedFields.description:
Uh oh! Updating an opportunity in Salesforce doesn't update the enrollment in Early Payments!

Let's start with the good news. If you move an opportunity to closed and configured in the test environment, and the rate won attribute is filled out greater than the floor rate of the program, an onboarding object is created in early payments. This is really cool! However, there are some problems.

1. The "Rate Won" attribute in Salesforce defaults to a value of 0.0%. This is translated to a 0 in the platform event. Early payments takes this 0, and sets it as the rate. The validation thinks that's input, and compares it to the floor rate, which will always be above 0, and throws a validation error. I think we need to allow 0.0% APR in a draft enrollment.
2. Moving an opportunity in Salesforce to closed and configured the first time works flawlessly. However, let's say that, as an account executive, I decide to change the "rate won" attribute on a closed and configured opportunity. Right now, that will throw an exception in early payments. This is unintended behavior - if someone updates something in Salesforce, it should also update the onboarding in early payments. This behavior can be added to look up if an existing onboarding object exists, and then update it with the new salesforce event.

issuetype.description: A problem or error.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
Uh oh! Updating an opportunity in Salesforce doesn't update the enrollment in Early Payments!

Let's start with the good news. If you move an opportunity to closed and configured in the test environment, and the rate won attribute is filled out greater than the floor rate of the program, an onboarding object is created _in early payments_. This is really cool! However, there are some problems.

1. The "Rate Won" attribute in Salesforce defaults to a value of 0.0%. This is translated to a 0 in the platform event. Early payments takes this 0, and sets it as the rate. The validation thinks that's input, and compares it to the floor rate, which will always be above 0, and throws a validation error. *I think we need to allow 0.0% APR in a draft enrollment.*
2. Moving an opportunity in Salesforce to closed and configured the first time works flawlessly. However, let's say that, as an account executive, I decide to change the "rate won" attribute on a closed and configured opportunity. Right now, that will throw an exception in early payments. This is unintended behavior - if someone updates something in Salesforce, it should also update the onboarding in early payments. This behavior can be added to look up if an existing onboarding object exists, and then update it with the new salesforce event.
fields.summary: Updating a closed/configured opportunity in Salesforce doesn't update the enrollment

renderedFields.description:
When an opportunity event is received from Salesforce there is a Email___c field which is compared to the userlist for the seller company. If the email is found, that user is added to the opportunity. If the user is not found, the full company userlist is added. This task is to modify the behavior so that

• The email comparison is case insensitive
• If the user is not matched, no users should be added, rather than all users.

Related code in IEP: https://github.com/Tradeshift/tradeshift-early-payments/blob/master/early-payments-service/src/main/java/com/tradeshift/earlypayments/onboarding/casemodel/OnboardingCaseAdapter.java#L530-L542

Opportunity event field details:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1u3dtpgzNqTFEEDjwrGDKG6b6QmGPRFqIn79u3_Uds18/edit#gid=0

renderedFields.customfield_10031:
- A document exists detailing all ways that we can assign a Tradeshift user to an enrollment from a salesforce opportunity.
- Each way has a list of pros and cons, and a realistic action plan.
renderedFields.description:
As a program manager, the user data I get from a Salesforce opportunity may not correspond with a user in the Tradeshift system.

  • Right now, there’s no way to save a user into early payments that doesn’t have an account in Tradeshift.

For example:

Salesforce Opportunity:

TS Company ID: 12fa-f23f-2d12-d12d

Account email address: brian.lutz@tradeshift.com

Tradeshift Company Account

TS Company ID: 12fa-f23f-2d12-d12d

Users on the company account:

  • User 1, tst@tradeshift.com
  • User 2, lnu@tradeshift.com

When the enrollment is made, the email address brian.lutz@tradeshift.com won’t match either of those users. Do we

  • discard this information
  • save it into the notes field of the enrollment
  • or create a user object in early payments even though it doesn’t exist in Tradeshift?
  • What other options are there?

It may be that the enrollment will just be in a draft state and Chris will have to reach out to the company and ask which Tradeshift user they’d like to use as their early payments manager. It also may be that we’ll work with the Copenhagen office to make a user in the tradeshift backend when the opportunity moves to closed/configured.

issuetype.description: Functionality or a feature expressed as a user goal.
issuetype.name: Story
